stream_context.summary: Kaze builds and tests the “Paint-Mario” retro section: players can color Mario, clear the canvas, and have their work judged by an in-level NPC. Most of the stream is spent coding the scoring logic, fixing resets, modelling the Coursebot evaluator, and discussing performance and technical curiosities.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a dynamic ‘virtual texture’ on Mario so the player can freely paint, with a button that clears the whole texture.
development_findings.quote: You can draw anything you want really… if you press this button here, it’s all gonna clear with the rocket.

development_findings.summary: Paint fill uses an iterative flood-fill stack stored in ROM memory because a recursive version would overflow the N64 stack.
development_findings.quote: The stack is not big enough for that… so I had to invent something.

development_findings.summary: Fixed bug where clearing the canvas didn’t reset the score, causing infinite points.
Current scoring: every mismatched pixel adds to a counter; if the value is below 1 000 000 the NPC awards the star. Threshold still being tuned.
development_findings.quote: I have it currently set to where if you get the number in the bottom-left corner below 1,000,000 then you get the star.

development_findings.summary: Decided against an ‘undo’ feature; only full reset is allowed to keep it a game challenge rather than an editor.
development_findings.quote: You don’t get undo, but you get reset. That should be good enough for you guys.

development_findings.summary: Chose Mario Paint ‘Coursebot’ robot as the evaluator NPC, built a high-poly (~300 tri) 3-D model from the original SNES sprites and positioned it on the ceiling.
development_findings.quote: This guy would be perfect… I guess it’s easiest if I just put him in the level somewhere and this is gonna run at 60 FPS anyway.

development_findings.summary: Switched Mario texture sampling to point filtering to keep pixel art crisp.
development_findings.quote: Oh yeah, that looks way more crisp. I don’t know why I didn’t try it.

development_findings.summary: Performance test shows full canvas clear runs at 60 FPS; memory wipe is fast enough for real hardware.
development_findings.quote: I feel like there might be a small delay… I mean, this is 50 FPS, so we’re good.

development_findings.summary: Mentioned still needing two new characters for the Yoshi Coin objective in the ice level.
Idea to asset-swap the whole hack (Mario + IP) and publish as an original indie game once finished.
development_findings.quote: If I swap Mario and all the others, that could be my first indie game.

development_findings.summary: Identified unsolved crash under Parallel RDP; currently recommends Project64 or other plugins.
development_findings.quote: We literally couldn’t figure it out… Project 64 Master Race.

development_findings.summary: Shared concept of hidden ‘ninth bit’ memory on N64 (~1 MB) and potential to exploit it for storage; plans a video explaining it.
development_findings.quote: Secretly, all the bytes on the N64 are nine bits… there are tricks to read and access the ninth bit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is married; casual mention his wife broke his large jug; they currently play Twilight Princess together.
Personal design philosophy: prefers exploration over dungeons in Zelda; dislikes 2-D platformers and boss fights.
context_findings.quote: Playing Twilight Princess, I realized that what I like in Zelda games is all the open world and exploration and not really the dungeons.

context_findings.summary: Financial note: Roblox is paying him to stream; plans a sponsored Roblox stream Sunday with community participation.
context_findings.quote: They’re paying me money to stream Roblox, like I’d be stupid not to take that.

context_findings.summary: Cautious about producing politically themed ROM hacks in current climate; fears backlash.
context_findings.quote: If I do the same thing in 2024 with a Trump 64 ROM hack, people will murder me.

zeina.summary: Enjoys playing Zelda games with Kaze in personal time; no direct development activity this stream.

key_stories.title: Building the Paint-Mario Minigame
key_stories.summary: Kaze transforms Mario into a drawable canvas, codes a flood-fill, adds scoring, models an NPC evaluator, and establishes gameplay rules (no undo, only reset).
key_stories.challenge: Create an engaging retro ‘Mario Paint’ challenge that runs on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Implemented virtual texture, iterative flood-fill, score metric, fixed bugs, and hand-modelled Coursebot to judge the art.
key_stories.outcome: Fully functional section that awards a star when player’s drawing is within tolerance; ready for tuning and polish.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s still a game, guys. This is not an image editor—you mess up, you lose your points.

key_stories.title: Discovering Hidden N64 Memory
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains a rarely used ninth bit in N64 memory that could yield ~1 MB extra space and muses about making educational content.
key_stories.challenge: Hardware limitation of 4 MB RAM inspires search for extra resources.
key_stories.process: Researches reading/writing the coverage bit and considers rendering micro-triangles to access every other byte.
key_stories.outcome: No immediate implementation but plans a technical video and potential in-game uses.
key_stories.key_quote: You’re never going to guess where this megabyte is… secretly, all the bytes on the N64 are nine bits.
